docs.lead_paragraph: Now that the town-hall-style meetings of the summer recess have more or less run their course, the two sides in the health care debate are moving to the next phase of guerrilla theater: public demonstrations. On Wednesday, supporters of a health care overhaul plan to stage vigils at more than 350 locations across the country, starting at 7 p.m. Under the banner of ''Can't Afford To Wait,'' the vigils are being organized by liberal groups, including Democracy for America, MoveOn, the Service Employees International Union and TrueMajority. Their goal is to put a human face on the need for the overhaul.
docs.abstract: Supporters and opponents of health care overhaul are planning to follow town-hall-style meetings during Congress's summer recess with public demonstrations (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Promote personal health by taxing sugary soft drinks. Make it easier for individuals to buy coverage by creating health insurance exchanges.
docs.abstract: Bipartisan group of economists and health care experts issues report outlining about one dozen diverse recommendations for health care overhaul; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Promote personal health by taxing sugary soft drinks.      Make it easier for individuals to buy coverage by creating health insurance exchanges.

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether people believe controversial statements about the health care overhaul depends on their political affiliation, a new survey finds. The survey, conducted in mid-August for Indiana University, says that when looking at statements the Obama administration says are myths, Republicans tend to believe the statements and Democrats tend to disbelieve them.
docs.abstract: Survey finds Republican respondents tend to believe statements about health care overhaul that Obama administration says are myths; Democrats tend to disbelieve them; finds independents believe some such statements but do not believe others (M)
docs.snippet: Whether people believe controversial statements about the health care overhaul depends on their political affiliation, a new survey finds.     The survey, conducted in mid-August for Indiana University, says that when looking at statements the Obama...

docs.lead_paragraph: They started hunting gray wolves in the high reaches of the Rocky Mountains on Tuesday, the first time in years that people have been allowed to shoot for sport this genetic cousin of man's best friend. For those who hate wolves and long for the era when they were wiped off the map, and for those who welcomed back this call of the wild, the last few days have revealed some dark feelings in the changing West -- and some strength of character as well.

docs.lead_paragraph: The proposed health care legislation emphasizes primary care and universal coverage, but will it help reverse the tide of health clinic closings in underserved areas like the north side of Milwaukee?

headline.sub: A Milwaukee Health Clinic Struggles to Stay Afloat

docs.snippet: The proposed health care legislation emphasizes primary care and universal coverage, but will it help reverse the tide of health clinic closings in underserved areas like the north side of Milwaukee?

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- President Obama is planning for "a new season" of more hands-on advocacy for his troubled domestic priority, an overhaul of the health care system, according to his advisers. Among the likely steps would be a nationally televised speech that close allies have urged, and a 10-year price tag for the overhaul below the $1 trillion mark.

headline.main: Obama Plans More Hands-On Health Advocacy

docs.abstract: Amid slipping support during the Congressional break, the president is likely to deliver a televised speech and for the first time put in writing the elements of a health care plan.
docs.snippet: Amid slipping support during the Congressional break, the president is likely to deliver a televised speech and for the first time put in writing the elements of a health care plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite concerns over what happens when government gets involved in health care, there is little difference between Americans on private health insurance plans and those on Medicaid or Medicare in rating the care they receive, according to Gallup Poll data.

headline.main: Rating Public and Private Health Insurance

docs.abstract: There is little difference in how Americans on private health insurance plans and those on Medicaid or Medicare rate the health care they receive, according to Gallup Poll data.
docs.snippet: There is little difference in how Americans on private health insurance plans and those on Medicaid or Medicare rate the health care they receive, according to Gallup Poll data.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Milwaukee Immediate Care Center, a nonprofit clinic serving an inner-city neighborhood, is teetering and health care proposals in Washington are unlikely to address its needs.
docs.snippet: The Milwaukee Immediate Care Center, a nonprofit clinic serving an inner-city neighborhood, is teetering and health care proposals in Washington are unlikely to address its needs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Incremental is the watchword for health care changes, as far as Senator Lamar Alexander of Tennessee is concerned.

headline.main: Republican Senator Calls for Only Incremental Health Care Changes

docs.abstract: Lamar Alexander, a member of the Senate's Republican leadership, recommended that lawmakers drastically scale back their goals for changing the health care system and plan instead to take smaller bites out of the problem.
docs.snippet: Lamar Alexander, a member of the Senate's Republican leadership, recommended that lawmakers drastically scale back their goals for changing the health care system and plan instead to take smaller bites out of the problem.
